text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian papers this morning:

-Former Planning Minister Terje Roed-Larsen was fined 50,000 crowns by authorities following an investigation into his share dealings 10 years ago with Norwegian company Fideco. Roed-Larsen, who resigned as a result of the scandal, denies he has done anything unlawful and says the authorities decision partly acquits him.
-The budget estimated four years ago for 33 large road, tunnel and bridge projects will over run by three billion crowns. The government is due to present new road plans to parliament in a few days.
-Slovakia has taken a step further towards NATO membership. On Tuesday, Europe's youngest nation signed a bilateral agreement on military cooperation with Norway.
-Scottish fish farmers receive five or six times more state financial support than their Norwegian counterparts, says a report from British consultancy firm Price Waterhouse.

-Norway will put more emphasis on the development of the global climate. Environment Minister Thorbjoern Berntsen says it should be as important as low inflation, low interest rates and low unemployment.
-International classification company Det Norske Veritas last year withdrew approval for 80 ships in spite of the owners wanting the vessels to remain registered.
